perturbation.original_text: Hereafter referred to as the "Company" or "AZUL", On the one part, AND: AVIONS DE TRANSPORT REGIONAL, G.I.E., a French groupement d'intérêt économique established under articles L.251-1 to L251-23 of the French Commercial Code, whose registered office is at 1 allée Pierre Nadot, 31712 Blagnac, France identified under Corporate and Trade Register of Toulouse number 323 932 236, Hereafter referred to as the "Repairer' or "ATR", On the other part.
perturbation.changed_text: Hereafter referred to as the "Company" or "AZUL", On the one part, AND: AVIONS DE TRANSPORT REGIONAL, G.I.E., a French groupement d'intérêt économique established under articles L.251-1 to L251-23 of the French Commercial Code, whose registered office is at 1 allée Pierre Nadot, 31712 Blagnac, France identified under Corporate and Trade Register of Toulouse number 323 932 236, Hereafter referred to as the "Service Provider' or "ATR", On the other part.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "Repairer" to "Service Provider" creates ambiguity. While ATR is still defined, the contract uses "Repairer" elsewhere. It's now unclear if "Repairer" and "Service Provider" have the same meaning and creates uncertainty regarding which obligations each party is binded to. Throughout the contract, the term “Repairer” is used, therefore the term “Service Provider” can be viewed as something completely different which is not clearly defined.

perturbation.original_text: WHEREAS the Repairer and the Company entered into a Global Maintenance Agreement as referenced here above (as amended and supplemented from time to time, hereafter referred to as the "GMA") for the purpose of providing the Company with Services for the maintenance of the Aircraft; and, WHEREAS in consideration of modification of the operations, the Repairer and the Company agree to amend the GMA in order to update the number of [*****] required for the invoicing; and, WHEREAS the Parties wish to amend certain provisions of the GMA upon the terms and conditions set out below.
perturbation.changed_text: WHEREAS the Repairer and the Company entered into a Global Maintenance Agreement as referenced here above (as amended and supplemented from time to time, hereafter referred to as the "GMA") for the purpose of providing the Company with Services for the maintenance of the Aircraft; and, WHEREAS in consideration of modification of the operations, the Vendor and the Company agree to amend the GMA in order to update the number of [*****] required for the invoicing; and, WHEREAS the Parties wish to amend certain provisions of the GMA upon the terms and conditions set out below.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "Repairer" to "Vendor" creates ambiguity about the entity responsible for the maintenance services and the entity required to update invoicing. If vendor isn't mentioned, it's uncertain if "Vendor" and "Repairer" refer to the same entity, leading to conflicting obligations regarding who is responsible for the update and invoicing process. The duties between the Service Provider and Company become misaligned.

perturbation.original_text: The Repairer, its Affiliates and/or its Subcontractors as applicable shall remain the exclusive owner of any intellectual property right related to the Services including: design of the LRUs, Main Elements, job cards, task cards, operating manual or industrial process, as relevant.
perturbation.changed_text: The ATR, its Affiliates and/or its Subcontractors as applicable shall remain the exclusive owner of any intellectual property right related to the Services including: design of the LRUs, Main Elements, job cards, task cards, operating manual or industrial process, as relevant.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "Repairer" to "ATR" leads to confusion about the party owning intellectual property rights. Since "Repairer" has already been changed to "Service Provider", replacing "Repairer" with ATR blurs the lines as to who owns the IP. If the “Service Provider” and “ATR” are not one in the same, there will be a conflict of intellectual rights.
